A Place further than the sky, A mediocre coming age series that overwhelmed by the seiyuu list. 
(i don't know about my literal translation but I hope this works as well)
first of all for those who seeking the cute girls doing cute things, well this series could be qualified to that qualification because from all 4 episodes that I watched there are none meaningful or memorable moments in this series, It started off with some girl thinks that "oh I want to do something great before I become adult but I always give up half-way and I wanted to do something for real now", metsome girl that wanted to be part of an expedition to the North Pole because her mother was missing there and she wants to find her. Everybody in the school finds her super weird because she was blabbering that she wanted to go to the north pole and all sudden the other girl said that she wanted to be part of it. so both of them embark a journey to the north pole (although there are more girls coming). 


For the record, as this series aired, Madhouse also released second season of Overlord which shares same lacking part, quality checking for animation because there are a bunch frame that I found very much rough or they purposely made it that way to skip steps and save money because they also release another series in this season. The other things that have been lacking are the pace of this anime which I felt is too fast for a slow paced theme like this. The composition of this series is good and the connection each character to another is very dynamic and  I love to see a great characterization like this. 


The Seiyuu list are no doubt filled with S and A class rated seiyuu such as Kana Hanazawa, Iguchi Yuuka, Inori Minase and my personal favourite, Hayami Saori. Kana Hanazawa proved herself as an A Rated Seiyuu in this series because she has been absolutely amazing throughout the series. The Minor roles for this series also filled with an A class rated seiyuu such as Lynn,  Ohara Sayaka, Kanemoto Hisako Hikasa Yoko and Others (yes I am very much seiyuu fags thank you very much).


A Place Further than the skies are undoubtedly a good anime, but not a memorable one. by the time this review was made it was running for 4 episodes, so I am very much hoping  this series could surpass my expectation

This review contains only minor spoilers for the beginning of the series.
There are two different ways to drive forward a story: To have things happen to the protagonists, or to have the protagonists MAKE things happen.  There's a writer's term for the latter: We call it Agency.  It's a powerful thing, maybe the MOST powerful tool in a storyteller's kit.  And Sora Yori is overflowing with agency, absolutely brimming with it, like water seeks release from any crack or opening in a vessel.
Sora Yori is girl power done right, better than any superpowers gifted by coincidence or gods or fate, better byfar than any shepherding by an older male character.  It's a story of four girls seizing their dreams, by themselves, and making them a reality.  That's real strength, and it's the core of this series; finding courage, finding competence and independence, finding peace in grief, and finding friendship.  A coming-of-age story at its very best, and packaged in enough honest charm to sugar-crash a whole damn colony of penguins.


And oh, baby, does Sora Yori have charm.  The characters are so distinctive and so likeable, each in their own way, and every bit of the show's humor and drama comes from their personalities and tendencies.  This is the kind of show you just sit and watch with a dumb, goofy grin on your face, in between bouts of laughter and tears.


That by itself would be enough, but there are story arcs here, too--especially for Shirase, who at first seems a supporting character, but rapidly emerges as Sora Yori's lead.  Each of the four girls is looking for something, and by the end, each has found it, in one way or another.  If there's a minor flaw in this near-perfect series, it's that none of the other characters have as powerful or emotional of an arc as Shirase; but then, even most shows featuring just ONE protagonist can't match the strength of her story.


And for all I've gushed about the writing, that's not Sora Yori's only strong suit.  The animation is fantastic.  There's little filler, and each of the show's several settings is captured perfectly.  The character designs are instantly recognizable and appealing.  Artistically, Sora Yori more than gets the job done, although it never quite elevates to soaring heights, except perhaps in the OP, one of the most magnetic and charming I've yet seen.


Speaking of which, the music is great, too--just like the art, it's excellent, though perhaps not masterpiece-level spectacular.


But again, you're here for the characters, and for their stories.  Grab a cup of hot tea, crank down the thermostat, and enjoy.

This anime is the reason i need to stop judging anime's by their covers. "Oh jeez, japan. This time, high school girls are going to ANTARCTICA?! Hard pass"
But someone convinced me. While it does have a few "Convenient" incidents and aligning of goals, it manages to make things believable throughout. Fair warning though: A piece of media has never made me sob so much before. The pain is so realistic because of how masterfully crafted the narrative is when it finally hits. Ouch, my feels. 
How did they managed to make the simple struggles of life, kinship, and a journey into the unknown into sucha highly emotional one? The layers peel back episode-by-episode and the fun and happiness becomes matched with the melancholy of tragedy and life itself. Friendship. Bitter acceptance. And learning to put one foot in front of the other. A place further than the universe is not so far after all when you find the right people.

This is a story about many things; youth, friendship, family, hardship, doubt, etc. But mostly it is about doing something crazy and getting out of your comfort zone. And this anime explores that perfectly.
The story starts out with one of our MCs, Mari, who dreams of doing something amazing before her youth ends. And everything starts from there. The people she meets, learning the value of family, the hardships she endures, and proving the doubters wrong from starting this journey are amazingly explored and it all started from "doing something crazy".
The message hit really hard, especially for me and maybe will for most of you.Because it fits perfectly in context in reflection of our community which is highly judged and considered outcasts. I bet most of us are insecure people in some degrees. Well go somewhere you've never been, eat something you've never tried, meet someone new, tell people you love  that you love them, aim for some crazy dream job in the future, etc. You only have one life, one youth.


Aside from the great messages this anime conveys, this anime is actually easy and light to watch. The scriptwriters found a great balance of light heart comedy, which is legit funny, and seriously touching moments, which is legit feels train.


In terms of presentation, I think this anime was well animated and has great cinematography. Madhouse has done a great job again, kudos to them.


This anime is great to watch in any mood. It is especially a must watch for slice of life lovers. You'll laugh, smile, and cry... and you'll love everything about it.

Once in a while, you come across a work of art that changes your outlook on life in a way or another. I didn't expect it to be a moe anime this time, but A Place Further than the Universe totally took me by surprise.
While the story isn't incredibly complex, it meshes the main cast's personal arcs with the main purpose of their adventure - finding the place where the crew had previously lost contact with Shirase's mom - very well. Being more or less a slice of life story, there isn't much plot to this show once they make it to Antarctica, but whatis there is executed on brilliantly. Moreover, the beginning of the story, where a lot of the conflict happens, is solid. The inner conflicts and difficulties encountered by the cast kept me interested and charmed the whole way through!


As for the art, the main four characters' designs are simple but of great quality; the rest of the cast also has good designs, complimented by solid animation and some of the truest-to-life, contagious facial expressions I've seen in anime. The background art is breathtaking for the whole show, from the bustling city to the snowy plains of Antarctica. All of these qualities help get immersed in the show completely!


Let's not forget the show's top tier voice acting, making the viewer empathize with the characters and helping make them true to life. The soundtrack is also always fitting and sweet, if a bit repetitive at times. I always looked forward to the OP putting me in the right mindset for the next episode, and I've had the ED stuck in my head for days. All in all, the sound design is fantastic and helps sell the reality of what the cast goes through. 


The characters themselves are the best aspect of A Place Further than the Universe. The characters' interactions are beautifully crafted and charming, and each of them have very human, very real personalities that mesh incredibly well with each other. Their different troubles back home and reasons to go as far as Antarctica to work on them, or get away from them, were all used in a great way to develop the characters during the whole show. Viewers are bound to relate to at least one of the four girls' difficulties and personality, and even when it's not the case, we're made to care about what happens to them. I've yet to come across a more wholly interesting cast in an anime. 


When it comes down to it, A Place Further than the Universe is a relatable, charming and wholesome adventure. At the same time, the themes brought up in the show - adulthood, friendship, grief, trust, living in the moment and the importance of people over material things will resonate with many. It's made me rethink a lot about how I live - and I'm ready to turn "I'll do it someday" into "Today, I'm doing it".

Following the journey of four girls to Antarctica, this anime presents a series of well-executed episodes that celebrate adventure, growth, honesty to oneself and above all, friendship. It's a pure and energetic story of youth without disregarding the difficulties of this lifestage.
For me, the most lasting impact of this anime will be the characters. Relatable, loveable and by no means perfect, each of them have something of their own to teach each other and you get to see the growth of their friendship. The love they have for each other is really infectious :3 
I really admired the execution of each episode - pacing, humour,and emotion of the anime were en pointe; they moved me to tears on multiple occasions. Much applause for the storyboard and animation. The realism was very appropriate for the setting, but it's also well incorporated into the plot and character development.


The OP and ED are pretty good too. The only drawback would be that the overarching plot of going to Antarctica was a bit weak, but with so many good and diverse moments and characters throughout the anime, it doesn't take away from the overall experience.


EDIT: The OP and ED gets better every time I listen to them - they're hidden gems alright :)

THIS SERIES IS NOT FOR THOSE WHO APPOROACH THE EVENTS LOGICALLY!!!
I'm absolutely simple anime watcher. High animation quality, complex scenario or  detailed shivering hair etc. doesn't matter for me. but feelings....
Sora Yori mo Tooi Basho simply based on feelings: Enjoy, excitement, sadness, separation and wanderlust. Do you like adventure? This series is for you.
It doesn't have any complex scenario or flashy anime effects. Sora yori contains two basics, reallly relastic characters and unlimited excitement. With each episode, you dive in a magical and at the same time realistic world. 
As I said, I can't ground my feelings. Animation was enough, music supports story tellingbut story wasn't unique. This series all about feelings just feelings\n\n\n

This Anime will think about How life is worth an adventure.
Sora Yori is one thing that suit for people how life is precious at a stake. Even tho it comes at a price, you must earn it hard to achieve that dream. Wishes and dreams may be common for every people in the world but this anime series is a special case.
There are times that the series will confuse a lot of viewers between the characters having personality problems and an adventure crumpled together. However, it did a great deal with the character development on how to cope up with every problems the character face.The Art style of the series gave me a ton of great experience which I had never seen before. The Atmosphere is real-like and managed to capture the Asian cities with its best landscape include the "dangerous continent".\n\n
I highly recommend this to everyone especially if you are basically a fan of unique splice of life adventure.

Madhouse me vuelve a sorprender de nuevo, pero esta vez no fue con anime sacado de un manga ni de una novela, sino que es original, propio de ellos. Y digo que sorprende porque es raro ver un anime original tan bien hecho como fue Sora yori mo Tooi Basho. En realidad dudaba si verlo o no, y en realidad, no me arrepiento de haberlo hecho. Madhouse de verdad sabe cómo ponerte los pelos de punta, este anime demuestra que hay más de una manera de disfrutar el anime, no siempre tienen que haber robots poderosos ni organizaciones secretas o un protagonista con un poderoculto o siquiera una trama profunda para ser algo maravilloso, a veces simplemente basta con ver el viaje de 4 chicas comunes y corrientes a un lugar más lejano que el espacio. Buen trabajo Madhouse y espero tus próximos proyectos :,)

This is my first time write a review on MAL and the first anime that i write review is Sora Yori mo Tooi Basho or A Place Further than Universe
If we see the visual and promotional video from this series, most people would think this is just another Cute Girls Doing Cute Things (CGDCT). But in the end this series went well beyond my expectation. It remains as Slice of Life (SoL) combined with the Adventure genre. But unlike the recent SoL anime which is mostly filled with comedy, romance and cute girls, Yorimoi manages to provides an interesting storyline, a good character development andbe able to touched our feeling.


STORYLINE : 9/10

Speaking of SoL anime, generally we will not find significant story and character development, especially when it is CGDCT. What we find is cute girls with a funny behavior in doing something plus the comedy element in it. But this anime is different. The main focus in this series is friendship. Each character has its own reasons for going to Antarctica, a reason that actually makes them meet when they never knew before. Indeed this series tells about adventures of the four main characters to Antarctic. But adventure is not always about finding and reaching something. /most important thing is the experiences that occurred during the adventure. The experiences that ultimately affect them to face their individual problems. This series still has a comedic element that is light and not excessive like any other SoL series, but what amazes me is this series can make us feel sad and cry when most of SoL series is made to make the audience enjoy.


DIRECTION : 9/10

The director of this series is the director who leads No Game No Life project, Atsuki Ishizuka. Viewed from the direction, I can conclude it in a sentence. this series can make us smile and laugh at the beginning to mid-episode, then slowly touch our hearts to be able to make us cry before the episode ends. Not many series are able to make transition of the atmosphere consistently in every episode. The thing I appreciate was presence of various foreshadow elements that are executed intelligently. At first we would think it was just a conversation or a casual scene, but it was all set to amplified the story in the final episodes. I also love the way they used background sign to supports every comedy in the story. Educational elements about the importance of expeditions to Antarctica is well presented. To me, this series has an incredible direction for a SoL series.


CHARACTER : 9/10

In a CGDCT series, we usually love a character because of some things like beautiful looks, silly but cute behavior or interactions between them that are very funny. But what makes the characters in this series loved is the development of their character and how they deal with each other's personal problems. Kimari who looks the most "stupid" but always able to keep the other characters to remain optimistic. Shirase is very nervous when in front of the camera but will be a straightforward person when expressing his feelings. Hinata is sometimes too wise but full of energy in their journey and Yuzuki who can I say the smartest among them but always confused with matters relating to friendship. These things are reinforced by the presence of classy voice actress like Inori Minase, HanaKana, Yuka Iguchi and Saori Hayami who were able to play the character well.


ART : 9/10

This anime is the original series from Studio Madhouse. We all know that Madhouse is one of the best anime studios in Japan. In this series even Madhouse works very well. Character design and light color selection are perfect for the SoL series. The existence of white color as a reflection of light reminds us to Tsuki ga Kirei art. But when it comes to background, Antarctic landscape, and scenes that have many movements. Madhouse delivers the same quality as when they made the action anime  series. One of my favorite scenes is the running scene on episode 2. Not only because the running scene has good animation, but the use of the background in provides the energetic atmosphere in the scene. 3D CG looks pretty neat so it does not look strange when combined with 2D images. In general, the animation in this series is executed well.


SOUND : 8/10

Sound became one of the things that made this anime good. The opening song is good, but I prefer the ending song that really describes the energy of the four main characters in this series. The thing that makes the story in this series so strong is the use of proper insert songs. Insert songs are always played towards the end of the episode and in that moment our hearts will be touched. However, because it only has 4 insert songs and is used more than 1 episode per song, there are some scenes that feel repetitive. Sound effects are also executed well.


Overall, I am glad not to miss this anime. This series is a refresher for the SoL genre that has only recently been filled by comedy and cute girls anime. This series proves that the SoL anime is not just about enjoyment and comedy, but also can provides an interesting storyline, good character development and on the one side can make us smile but on the other side can make us shed tears. If you're a fan of SoL anime but need an interesting and significant storyline. This is for you.

This was more wholesome than expected. Madhouse takes another W with Sora Yori Mo Tooi Basho (A Place Further Than The Universe).
It's a great tale of friendship and adventure that makes you wanna get up, throw your laptop away and embark on a journey to some place far away. It's cute, funny, emotional, relatable and powerful, It is well paced and has some extremely good moments. The portrayal of friendship is it's strongest attribute, especially When it comes to Hinata and Shirase, it really makes you wish you did these things in your life or will attempt to do. It's an anime that can trulymove you. The Music and Animation are nothing special but works superbly for the nostalgic vibe of the show. There are some memorable songs and bgms though. The characters are lovable and interesting, their development and interactions can be a real treat to watch. Everything they experience feels so real and they seamlessly made us connect with their experience. The VA's have also done a splendid job voicing these characters. 


Negatives are it can get cliched at times and it did fell a bit anti-climatic, maybe cause I wish they spent more time or did more things in the Antarctic, a couple more episodes of even filler with a couple more challenging tasks would've done it, But it's no biggie, they did end it perfectly, Like perfect in every sense of the word, which is good cause the last thing I want to do is wait for a Madhouse sequel of a great anime. If they do give us a season 2 I would prefer a time skip. Just saying.


Highly recommend this anime, it's just so fun and moving. Especially if you enjoy genres like Shoujo/ Slice of life/ Adventure, do not miss this one. I'm giving it an 8.25/10.

Honestly, when I first starting watching this anime I thought it was another one of those cute girls, in a cute world, doing cute things type of anime. However, I was wrong. I can say with confidence that this was probably one of the greatest anime I've watched this season!
--------------
Story: 10
--------------
At first, the story may seem bizarre, think about it, would you ever shout out about going to Antartica in front of your classmates? However, I must say I enjoyed it, I actually really liked the whole idea of high school girls going to an uninhabited land. It really did blow me and my friendaway with the strong direction it was headed, and good writing. This story was truly super unique in its own way and would get me excited every episode.


--------------------------

Art & Animation: 10

--------------------------


As expected of Ishizuka, Atsuko (the director of No Game No Life) and Madhouse, the animation was really topnotch. Throughout the whole anime, I could say that every single scene was really well done. I honestly don't have any complaint what so ever.


--------------

Sound: 7

--------------


The Openings and Endings weren't this shows strongest points compared with something like the Animation. Even so, I would say this the opening would be on my top 10 opening list for this season. The opening really sets the mood, gets you into the action and above all else, it was beautifully displayed. The voice acting for our main four characters were on point. The voice actors really did an excellent job of portraying high school girls.


------------------

Character: 7

------------------


I didn't have too many complaints about the characters, yes there were characters like Megumi, which I just didn't understand what her point was. But our main characters I really didn't have an issue with. They had their strengths and weaknesses throughout the series. The rest of the supporting cast, did their job right, by supervising our main cast to Antartica, which really makes the whole series seem more realistic.


-----------------

Enjoyment: 9

-----------------


This series was definitely really enjoyable, it had many funny moments, but what really made this series interesting for me, was the whole theme of going to an uninhabited land and supporting one another on the way. If you skipped this anime this season, just because it seems like, it's one of those cute girls, doing cute things, in a cute world type of anime, I truly feel sorry for you.


-------------

Overall: 9 

-------------

Overall, the story was fantastically told, it was going in a strong direction, the general idea was also great. Everything to do with Art and Animation was simply unquestionable amazing. The sound aspect was solid, the main four characters fitted in with each other perfectly, supporting one another. However, it's because of this reason I really just see no reason for Megumi to be apart of the story. This anime got me laughing multiple times and makes someone like me, (still in high school) think of using my think productively and not let every second go to waste!

This is one of those slice of life series that goes beyond the expectancy.
Every episode in the series so far are well thought and written. This goes in two directions, the development of the story and characters. Even though the idea of high school girls going to the Antartida is crazy, is well thought.
The first three episode introduce you to the main characters, they even explain the reasons of why every girl wants to journey to the Antartida and by that form a bond of friendship you don't see often nowadays. After that is mainly about the journey the girls have, in and out.
Every episodecan manage the youth and inexperience of the girls, without going to borderlands of stupidty that many slice of life do. The dreams and hopes they have and how they grow by reaching them is managed well.\n\n
The series can be enjoy by both women and men, because the themes goes beyond the high school girls cliche series. It is about life itself so it's very emotive in almost every aspect. As for my experience I've watched every episode on the edge of dropping a tear.\n\n
The story is more than decent. The art is very well polished. The sound is good, emotive when it wants to be, silly when it needs. The characters are awesome, and the enjoyment is good, like a roller coaster.\n

This anime was near perfect for me. It was incredibly realistic and grounded. It also balanced drama and comedy excellently and a way that no anime I've seen so far has matched. It was incredibly well-paced and took its time in every beat of the story for the viewer to soak it in. The flashbacks were used to the greatest effect in the second half of the series. I especially loved how Kimari and Megumi's friendship was used naturally to develop Yuzuru's characterization on the boat. Hinata was a cheerful character who also had her own demons to face. I loved how she would makeup quotes. However, I wish her arc was foreshadowed like Yuzuru's arc and had more screentime dedicated to it. Nonetheless, it was a nice way to reference the show's themes in a humorous way. Shirase was characterized very well and the writers did an excellent job in making her struggle, her motivations, her insecurities, feel real. 


The animation was great, especially when they reached Antartica. The OST was downright excellent. Sora Wo Miagete was inspiring and really stirred my heart. Haru ka Tooku set the atmosphere well. Mata ne was probably my favorite with such a melancholic and powerful feel that I'll never forget. The ending of the anime was excellent and resolved everything perfectly.


Another thing is that Yuzuru's arc was kind of dwelled on a little too long when it didn't need to be. While this hampered the story almost not at all, it did make me realize that Yuzuru could have been characterized a litle bit better compared to the rest of the main cast.

“A Place Further Than the Universe” invokes the feeling of youth and being able to take on the world and be able to do anything. I am 20 years old now, so still pretty young, but just like Kimari in the show I sometimes have the feeling that my youth is passing me by. This show encourages the viewer to try something new and live their life to the fullest everyday. The message behind this show and its story is very touching to me and I would highly recommend this show to anyone. 
The art and sound of this show is top notch. A lotof detail were put into the environment and the character design of every scene. The art definitely stands out during the blizzard arc near the end of the show. The Arctic scenary was beautifully animated. The opening song is catchy “The Girls Are Alright”, but in my opinion the best song on the soundtrack is “Haru Ka Tooku”. It does a good job of delivering during the emotional scenes of the show and is definitely memorable. 


The Characters and their development are one of the most pivotal parts of this show and it is a treat to watch. I cannot see this show being as good without the four main girls. All four girls have their different reasons for wanting to go to Antarctica and the show explores them. Watching their friendship grow from barely knowing each other to best friends is also satisfying. 


Even though this show did a lot of things right I do have a few complaints. In a few moments during the show I felt that some of the drama felt forced and unnecessary. It seemed they were just trying to provoke some emotion from the viewer. Also, the believability of the show and the whole premise of four highschool girls traveling to Antarctica despite how dangerous it is, is a bit of a stretch though. It does provide good reasoning behind why they are finally allowed to go so it can slide. 


I really enjoyed this show. It exceeded my expectations greatly. It comes with  a few inspiring messages about living life to the fullest, human relationships, and moving forward. If you are looking a slice of life adventure this is definitely the show for you.

This would probably a nominee for the anime of the year award. The whole series is great. I love the slice of Life and Comedy combination of the show, with a bit of drama included. I really want to give it a perfect 10, but sadly, I saw a few hiccups on the whole series. First of all is the first episode. The first episode should be the one who hooks the viewers up. But the first minutes of the first episode is paced too slow and boring. Second would be the character development. Its kinda dissapointing especially the idol girl who has a sadistpersonality, its just doesn't fit with her. Following up would be the adventures in antarctica. I mean, the episodes should show more of their adventures, like what they did in the opening song. Maybe they should have a little bit of excitement and not just stuck in their camp or base. I waited for them to do what they all did in the OP but I waited for nothing. So sad. The last would be the drama / sad part. I know this is a sliceoflife/comedy anime. The part were the girls cry when the other girl opened the laptop of her mom. Its sad. But they should add more sad moment to it. You know, to make us cry more. And make a perfect ending to the series. But oh well. Enough of the negatives, I praised how good the animations are. The background, the use of cgi, character design and many more. Madhouse is on fire! I also love how they went to singapore, kinda tired seeing all animes placed in Japan. They did a pretty good job animating the buildings in singapore and the durians too. I also praised how realistic the series is! The snowcats, the blizzard, the ship, the helicopter, their base, their gadgets and many more. Even the small details is really on it. They did a huge research apply it in the series. Lastly, I comend the director for the giving the anime a great flow. The characters are so lively, the comedy is so good, and the background scenes is well picked on every episode. Such a great synchronization to all of it. The op song is not that good actually, but the ED is somewhat better than the OP. Overall, a great anime! 9/10

Read the simple synopsis of "Four high school girls visiting the South Pole" and you're dumb-founded. And you ask yourself, "Is this really going to work out?" or "What has anime come to?" I know I had that same thought before this show premiered. And boy was I proven wrong. And here's the reason why..
Story (8/10)
Nothing to write home about here. The simple premise of "Four high school girls visiting the South Pole" is a good way of giving the story. However, what happens internally within, is something to write home about and express deeply. More will be discussed in the "Character" section of thisreview.



Animation (9/10)


MADHOUSE. The legendary, known studio that worked on modern classics such as Death Note, One Punch Man, and many more. They brought life to the art showcased in Sora Yori. Detailed scenery, brilliantly vibrant colors, and fluid animation. Character designs aren't too unique but tailor to the archetype of that character well. Overall, please watch Sora Yori on a legal streaming site with high-definition, it'll bring so much life to this already lively show.



Sound (9/10)


Though nothing really stood out to be in the OST so far. They are well-fitting to what the show has to offer in each scene. Whether it be emotional, fun, or dramatic. The music played in that particular scene fits well. The opening song is particularly fun, but the true feeling of the show is orchestrated perfectly through the ending theme. The show's voice actors brilliantly sing a melody that is accompanied by a vibrant animation with deep meaning in what the show is truly about.


The voice actors feature a cast of well-known voice actors. Inori Minase, Saori Hayami, Kana Hanazawa, and Yuka Iguchi. And how well do they express their characters in this show. They did an amazing job as expected from top class voice actors. Performance in the EDs is brilliantly harmonized together, just like their character chemistry which brings us to the next section.



Character (10/10)


Character development is where Sora Yori fully shines. From a slice of life lover like myself, Sora Yori expresses one of the most dynamic character chemistry I have seen. I compare the chemistry to shows like K-ON and Love Live which heavily rely on strong character interactions to create a ranging "taxonomy" in Slice of Life shows. Archetypes in this show aren't fully obvious at first and don't stick to a generic expectation from what you'd expect in other "cute girls doing cute things" series. As you progress through the show, you'll find their drive and passion for wanting to do what they do. Their past, that delivers strong story-telling to help attach yourselves to the characters strongly. Each character has their own specific past that they gloom over, and each story is well told evenly throughout the series. Overall, Sora Yori showcases strong character/development to create relatable themes and situations that bring somewhat of an inspirational vibe towards watching it.



Enjoyment (10/10)


As previously mentioned, I am a Slice of Life junkie. However, that doesn't mean I find all Slice of Life shows amazing. There are many Slice of Life shows that I found generic or just flat out boring since I felt a rinse and repeat feeling for them. However, Sora Yori brought something that felt inspirational and entertaining. I strive off strong character chemistry, and that's what Sora Yori delivered. Also the idea of dropping everything and pursuing a passion with your friends is something that I heavily relate to.



Overall (9.2/10)


Without taking the story into account. This show, I can say, is the pinnacle of Slice of Life series. With a simple, yet effective story, vibrant art/animation, strong character chemistry, and an all-star cast of voice actors. Sora Yori is a show not to be missed and thrown out the door cause of the premise. Looking deeper in something off-putting can surprise you, like what this show did for me.

Let me start by saying that this is already my favourite anime of the year and it's gonna be pretty hard to find a better one even if we still have three seasons of anime to go!
Story: What started as a girl who wants to go to Antarctica turned into a beautiful story about friendship. At first I did not know what to expect from this anime, but it surprised me with it's honesty and the lack of cliche - plus it instantly charmed me and melted my heart.
Art: The art is actually why I started watching it! I loved the light colors, the artstyle and the fluidity of the animation.


Sound: Emotional and piercing and amazing! 


Character: My favourite part of the show - I just loved seeing their friendship evolve. Each character was growing up and had their own lessons to learn. It was beautiful to witness their evolution.


Enjoyment: Do I need to say? I ABSOLUTELY LOVED IT! And I cried so much during it.


Overall: What can I say? I fell in love with this anime and I never wanted it to be over. 10/10

Sora Yorimo Tooi Basho won't be everyone's cup of tea. It’s not an edge-of-your-seat adventure series rife with peril or action, nor is it even all that climactic in general. Objectively speaking, though, it is the best show I’ve seen so far from the Winter 2018 season.
A blend of static imagery, extreme close ups, and even point-of-view perspectives reinforce the curious, adventurous nature of the story. Meanwhile, the mix of inspiring and sentimental music enhance its overall sense of wonder. The character development is what really won me over, though. Each member of the main ensemble noticeably changes over the course of the narrative, asdo many of the supporting characters. That’s worth recognizing for a series spanning only 13 episodes.\n\n
Should you choose to embark on this journey to the Antarctic, you may find yourself overcome with a warm, fuzzy feeling and sense of wanderlust. A sensation that lasts for maybe 20 minutes, followed by the sad realization that never, in your own life, will you ever likely experience the same kind of journey or personal growth the characters in this show achieve.

Why I gave this a 10/10!!! 
Because I love this series!! I cried, I laughed, I shared some pain, I related to it so well. 
Is because it deserves it! For an anime original to do this well is OBVIOUSLY hard thing to do. 
It was such a fantasy series. In my opinion this series not only was able to capture youth, struggles, and understanding oneself fantastically, the music and the concept was just amazingly done. Carefully thought out. Shirase was definitely the MVP in the last couple episodes. Whether you are old, young, active, or not. This series captures many people who always wantedto step outside their comfort zone and explore. 


The character development was fantastic, you really see growth in all the characters. You watch as Mari change from being scared and not doing anything to exploring Antartica, and going out with Shirase, doing things she usually don't do. Living her youth. And then you have Yuzuki who doesn't trust in "friends" because of her past experience. Seeing that she opens up to Hinata, Shirase, and Mari and starts being more happy. You have Hinata, strong willed, not wanting to tell the other girls her feelings, she was a mystery until close to the end opening up to the rest of the girl about being betrayed by her so called friends in her old high school. THEN WE HAVE THE BEST GIRL Shirase the one who literally triggers them all to live life, to travel with her to Antartica. Not just that, we she her struggle, with people making fun of her, letting her down, saying she won't make it to Antartica, she even struggles internally knowing that her mother is gone. But she still wants to go there and see what her mother did. Seeing her change through out the whole series was WORTH IT!. The fact all these girls are able to contribute to each other, is amazingly done. 


The story itself is intriguing, you have 4 girls who don't really know each other going to A PLACE FURTHER THAN THE UNIVERSE, for all different reasons. But one place remains the same. 


The music of course was FANTASTIC too. The amazing execution of the music into the most important scenes was great, can't say much, I recommend going to listen to the songs! 


Of course the Art was amazing!! The sceneries were awed! I personally have seen the aurora in person, I was awed and amazed as much as these girls was.  


This probably a basic as hell thing to say, I've seen a lot of anime, never made an review until this one, and this one was definitely a great one. I recommend to watch it. OF COURSE everyone has their own taste and opinion. These are mine. :D


Enjoyment? If I could give it an outstanding series award, I would! 10/10

This show was utterly charming. 
The plot is pretty straightforward, "cute girls go to Antarctica", and thus all the story is driven through the characters, and it is here that the show really shines. The main characters are well drawn and engaging with distinct and slightly exaggerated (in a good way) personalities. Each girl is somewhat broken and grows throughout the series in ways that are relatable and believable. The story is told with such passion and I cried at the end of a bunch of episodes. The supporting cast are impressively done too, especially given this is a single cour show and almost allthe focus is on the main girls. 


The art is fantastic and remarkably well animated, especially for a show where the visuals aren't really the point, but they add so well to the overall feel. The sound design is stellar, although the music (while excellent) is slightly limited in range.


I know this review is short and slightly incoherent, but if you are reading this then just go and watch it, regardless of your preferred genre it has a lot to offer anyone.


Overall 9.5/10

I can't describe how much I loved this anime but I will try to. It's a heartwarming story, one I haven't seen in a very long time. 
Each character has it's own unique way of being. The story is so well written that motivates me as a screenwriter to push further on the boundaries that society and myself have established. I enjoyed it every bit since the very beggining to the end. I would give a standing ovation to this one and I hope so much people in the world would watch it because this anime is not one that you can miss. 
After watchingit all I can say it has changed my life in a good way that, like I said, I can't describe on words. I would recommend this anime to anyone that is eager to go on adventure with the girls. I laughed and cried so much and I still am. It's truly a masterpiece.

Have you ever felt that there’s something missing in your life? That you don’t have any real complaints, but everything just feels meh? Like you want to go far, far away and leave civilization behind, to a place where you can just be free? 
No? Me neither.
But that doesn’t mean I can’t relate to Kimari and the others on some level. 
Kimari is a girl who wants to stop aimlessly meandering through life. She makes the intial decision to go to Antarctica on a whim – a spur of the moment thing – but after that the determined face comes on and she tries herhardest to turn the decision into a reality. She’s a bit of an airhead, carefree, and clumsy with words, but also deeply caring and forgiving. She injects life into the party and when she laughs it’s for real.


Shirase is Kimari’s opposite in a lot of ways. Seemingly stubborn, aloof, brusque, and an intellectual to boot, at some times she’ll be the most immature of the group but at other times show a maturity far beyond her years. Her reason for going to Antarctica is to do with her mother, whose footsteps she’s trying to follow in. That’s already a very different reason to the others. They came to escape, she came to discover. Which she does. On the journey, the wall she’s put up around herself begins to crack, and a sensitive and fiercely loyal person emerges. Shirase’s development is in my opinion hands down the best in the anime.


Hinata is essentially the mother of the group. She supervises the others, knows what to say in most awkward situations, tempers Shirase’s stubbornness, and acts as a buffer between Shiraishi’s stick in the mud attitude and Kimari’s carefree one. This isn’t to say she never makes mistakes (which she does), but she’s the kind of character who is very hard to dislike. As with most perpetually cheerful characters, there’s a lot more to her than meets the eye, and seeing her open up to the others and finally move on as a person is one of the most sweet and satisfying scenes in the anime.


Shiraishi, the last member of the party, is a little different. Barring the ridiculous circumstances in which she meets the others, she seems the most unnecessary of the four. All the girls are insecure on some level – which is fine because in life most people are, and that’s what the journey’s for – but Shiraishi’s insecurity goes beyond theirs. It is understandable, given her background, and she does have quite a lot of screen-time devoted to her development, but there’s no closure in the same way there is for the others; no real sense of moving on. Or maybe that’s just how I felt about it. Either way, she’s a business-like, shy and sweet but lonely girl who just wants friends.


A lot of the drama does feel more like melodrama, especially when Shiraishi is involved. There are some maturely handled moments (in relation to Shirase’s mother, for example - those scenes were brilliant) but it does seem to switch between heavy and lighter topics less than gracefully in some cases. There are a few heavily dramatic parts that are immediately followed by comic relief parts, but rather than serving to lighten the mood they lessen the impact of the drama and make it look silly rather than deep.

All the technical stuff in relation to Antarctica – the voyage, the equipment, the techniques used by explorers – seem pretty good. I don’t know enough about it to say whether it’s accurate or not, but I understood it well enough all the same. It does feel like the creators have researched at least.


Most of the storyline consists of switching between focussing on the journey itself and focussing on the drama in the quartet. It’s mostly well thought-out and well-paced but does include one completely unrealistic plot point compared to most of the story. I get that they needed to find a way to bring Shiraishi along, but surely there could have been some other way to bring the girls together? I mean this here was a MMO Junkie level coincidence. I won’t spoil exactly how it’s done, and after all it is only a means to cause them to meet, but I will say I watched that part in sheer disbelief and with a large amount of cynicism.


The art and animation are fantastic, and the music changes in all the right places to match the mood shifts. The Op is really catchy and feels like the prelude to an adventure.


My one caveat is that, despite the many good aspects of the anime, I could never really get that into it. I liked the characters, but in a more detached way – I didn’t generally laugh or cry with them. I think that’s partly because of the major tone shifts (drama to comedy and back), partly because I found some of the technical stuff a bit boring after a while, and partly because I’m just not that into travelling. No guarantees that you’ll feel the same though, for all I know one of these aspects could be the best part of the show for you. 😊


To sum up: if you like series about self-discovery through adventure, complete with a lot of drama and an actual end goal in sight, try watching this. The cute girls are just a bonus. XD

Agree or not, this season of Winter 2018 was dominated by drama genre. Two competitors of my version of best anime of this season were both drama anime and Sora Yori mo Tooi Basho, an original anime by Madhouse, managed to go there and inspired me to reach my dream even its impossible, because four high school girls can make their dream come true, why me, a 21 years old woman who struggled in her last year of college, cannot do that.
The major plot of this anime is quiet simple actually, a journey to live the youth at its fullest and they did that withgoing to Antarctica. What I want to underline is how careful each of the character being handled especially the four girls that was in the center. Each one of them have a problem that they want to overcome and this journey to Antarctica really reshape them all to overcome their problems. Sometimes, when you have a problem to overcome, what you need is a journey for a self discovery and overcome your problem.


For the sound, they really have good opening, ending, and insert songs. That opening is really catchy that sometimes I have that song on a roll and listen to them over and over again. But what I really want to say about the soundtracks is of course that insert song that always played when the timing is perfect. Yes, when the emotion were overflowing. That insert song really made the situation more emotional and pushed us to spill our tears even further.


The animation is really good. This is where Madhouse specializes in and they wanted to try to do that in cute girls doing cute things animation and they did it. I think it's worth to point at because they really did a good job at animating cute girls doing cute things and I wish they do the same or better in the future.


Overall, Sora Yori mo Tooi Basho is a dark horse in the season. Coming out of nowhere to shine in the end. Sadly, this anime is not really being watched by the community in my country. I just really want them to know that Sora Yori mo Tooi Basho is worth to be labeled as one of the best anime of the season.

I've just finished watching all the episodes and now I'm full with satisfaction. This is definitely one of great anime ever.
A Japanese word 'Seishun' is a vague one. Many know a term 'Seishun' but no one can explain it. This is typical especially for teenagers, who are really in 'Seishun.' The young never understands what is 'Seishun,' eagerly hoping for enjoying it.
Mari, a protagonist of this work, is one of such female high-school students. Initially she was just dreaming of enjoying 'Seishun.' Then, after a bit odd encounter with Shirase, she decided to go to the South Pole. This anime depicts how Mari, Shirase, andother two heroines, Hinata and Yuzuki went through hardships and shined in a place further than the universe ('Sora yori mo Tooi Basho.')


Yes, 'Seishun' is a kind of light. Like spark, those who are in 'Seishun' emit something bright. This fact is the main theme of this prominent anime.


Throughout the series, four protagonists intentionally or unintentionally sparked so much. They all had trouble; some had a tragic episode with the South Pole, while some had retired high-school. Though so, by, or after, deciding to making a long journey, their lives dramatically started to change as everyone got surprised.


The only difference between heroines and other mobs is whether s/he rushes into one's dream or not. Protagonists never looked back ways they had passed; they just saw their common dream. They just ran through their young ages, shining vividly.


After all, 'Seishun' is presented to those who are trying something with enthusiasm. Mari and three heroines is telling us that fact.


This anime conveys us it in various ways. Direction and photography give us how protagonists shine with much amount of metaphor: blinking city lights of night Shinjuku, aurora, and so on. Splash of waves and crystals of ice could be counted, for they reflect light effectively and just for a instance they flash, like girls in 'Seishun.'


Even the ending song tells us their brightness. Memorable introduction is consisted of a notes of keyboard. Each sound contains much brightness and lightness than the ordinal piano, which give us impression of dazzling sparkles. We have to consider why this loop of keyboards always streams throughout the entire song.


Heroines were worn glittering lights by such techniques and step by step they solved their own problems, leading by the shine of 'Seishun.' Each episode has both comical conversations and a moving end. Every time we finish one of episodes we feel something warm in our heart. Watching over heroines' growing, we remember our young days and seize what is 'Seishun' without any word.


A work which tells us what we cannot explain verbally has tremendous value. In this sense, 'Sora yori mo Tooi Basho' is a genuine art; it is a masterpiece in today's anime culture. We should celebrate this rare appearance of the work, and praise excellent staffs of MadHouse, the studio.

This anime blew away my expectation. I expected that this anime would be an average anime, with some touch of drama and SoL feels - but....boom!
Story 8/10
This anime has very simple story, but it's developed pretty well. It's about some girls going to antartica, but played with a realistic approach. From the harshness of reality, the works of "luck" to the result of hardwork - we can see all of them here. I expected this anime had an approach like K-On, or Yuru Camp or etc - and nope, it's beyond them in the term of heavyness. 
Art 8/10
People from madhouse sure did a goodjob. At the very first scene, in eps 1 - the animation kind of staggers. My low expectation became a reality. But then i watched the opening song and the animation was pretty well made. From there until the end, we can see a stable of quality in the aspect of animation.


Chara design? It's cute, isn't it? This what makes my expectation quite low to begin with. In the core, this anime is still "anime with cute girl doing cute things", but that's what makes this chara design works well.


The background is so....it made me wonder whether people from madhouse really went there just to take some photos so that they could draw it in a realistic manner. The quantity of scenery porn in this anime isn't that much, but yes, they exist as backgrounds in some episodes.


Sound 7/10

Can't say much about this, it's fairly good from the seiyuus, OP, ED and all. But one thing that i have to note is : the penguin gives a sound truly like a penguin does.


Character 8/10

This anime may has some casts that may feel relatable and unrelatable at the same time. But all of them still being played in a realistic manner. Their seriousnees feels real. Their sadness, their emotion etc - pretty well played. This anime can depict the characteristics of its cast very well.


Enjoyment 8/10

For sure, some people might not be able to enjoy this anime. But if you are able to enjoy such as Sakura Quest, Shirobako or might be Yuru Camp (SoraYori isnt as laid back as Yuru Camp - note), you may find this anime enjoyable. For me, personally, this anime took a pretty generic theme as its core but could bring it to much further place than what that "generic theme" usually brings - this is what i find enjoyable.

I'm so glad I got on this train early, because this is easily one of the hidden gems of the current season.
Fun characters (comparable to the girls from K-ON, as another user pointed out, but I feel they're a little more nuanced than that), good art, good animation, good music, and we have ourselves a winner! Also, the synergy between the multiple elements was simply mind-boggling. This is the kind of stuff that gets people addicted.
The music wasn't the best in the industry, but it is absolutely perfect for the show. The animation isn't the best in the industry, but it fits the flow ofthe show. See what I'm getting at? Synergy. This show has it. One thing, however, that I was truly impressed by was the art, and I don't mean the background or the detailing. The color palette is what I'm referring to here. The artists decided to go with a slightly warm color scheme, and I'm all for it. It creates a nice juxtaposition with the theme of the show, them going to Antarctica and all.\n
Coming to the music. It isn't the absolute best, but it works like a charm. To put things into a clearer view, I probably wouldn't listen to the OST or the OPs outside of the anime, but every time they DO play in the anime, my heart just melts. Everything just flows together. \n
The story however, is nothing amazing. It's aided by the rest of the show, in my frank opinion. That said, it is FAR from bad, as it gets the basics right. Good, but not excellent character development (blame that on its short run time), and a plot that progresses ever so slightly every episode. The character arcs are very-well defined, which to some, might take away from the magic, but in my experience, this saves time and space for the actual bulk of the emotion.\n
And if there's anything this show has, it's emotion. It has heart. It's impossible to be a cynic while watching this show. Your heart will melt at some point. It's as simple as that. \n
So, to conclude: Yes, you should watch this show. It is amazing.

What can i say.
Sometimes you start a new anime just looking for something light to watch, and for your surprise is a very good anime, with a beautiful story and amazing animations and details.
I have learned more about the Antarctica with this 13 episodes than in my entire high school.
The music is very good, i love the ending. 
The interactions between the 4 main characters and the support characters are really good, not forced at all. I wish it could had more episodes so the past of the other characters can be explored. 
At the end This is one of those little treasures that youhave to discover every season. \n
A very good anime indeed.

So, I heard about this anime and thought to myself "Somehow a few high school girls go to Antarctica...just like that.  Because that's a thing kids can do.  Sounds ridiculous."
It's not ridiculous.  At all.  It's well explained and their reasons are mostly reasonable.  One is looking for her mother who when on a previous expedition.  One wants to experience SOMETHING before she's too old.  Another is a sort of youtube star who has to go for publicity.  The other...I guess she's just along for the ride.  These girls, though.  They are amazing.  Just thinkfor a moment about how much courage it takes to go on this sort of expedition and how much training it takes to make it.\n\n
But it's the story.  The story is GOOD.  The characters are GOOD.  And the art is outstanding.  Watch this.

What really outstands this anime is the level of charisma added to the main characters. Each of them are very well developed and you end up caring for them, relating to them, understanding them. This should be used as a main reference when it comes to great character development.
"A place further than the universe" depicts very well common themes of adolescence, such as anxiety, the urge to live remarkable experiences, the need for friendship and what it really means, the coming of independence and the development of self-confidence. The very relatable cast and the addition of extremely well written dialogue makes everything feels very convincing.
Theart style is beautiful. The art direction is great and the animation doesn't let down. \n
The soundtrack is awesome and it all combined makes this simple, yet daring anime be one of the greatest in recent years. It really is that great and I highly recommend it to anyone who's into "slice of life" genre. Don't miss this one!

There are many wonders of this world, and those who don’t experience these directly miss out on life-changing possibilities. However, given the opportunity to become a potential wonder, A Place Further than the Universe gets so close but ultimately fails to achieve this feat.
The pilot episode was amazing. No doubt about that. It effectively set up the rest of the series while concurrently being artistically intriguing and spectacular. However as the show goes on, it goes from being an inspirational adventure to a generic cute-girls-doing-cute-things reality show.
I will certainly not deny that I enjoyed this show; however, there were several times this show putme in an apathetic gaze. And I get it, sometimes it’s impossible for a series to manage to maintain a plateau at its peak, but A Place Further than the Universe, unfortunately, experiences a detrimental distance from its peak to its lowest point. From several disposable characters to just random, cliche, episodic drama, this series has many flaws. For instance, there is no foundation for strong character development(except for maybe one of the protagonists).


What are we left with then? Well, we have four hilarious, innocent girls living their best life. While this by itself is the major substance of many other series out there, this alone can’t bring about greatness and differentiate the series from the variety of great titles out there. A Place Further than the Universe, unfortunately, ends up in this category.


Near the end of this series, A Place Further than the Universe genuinely attempts to return to its initial finesse. As, not only the characters’, but also the viewers’ journey comes to a close, the show displays the satisfaction of accomplishing the initial hopes and dreams of the characters. It finally builds upon the character’s previous ambitions and troubles that was crucial to the pilot’s success.


There are parts of this show that I constantly enjoyed. To begin with, the melodious soundtrack was extremely proficient in relaying the emotions of certain scenes (bangers, I tell you, bangers). Artwork and voice acting was a pleasure as well (I enjoyed the No Game No Life easter eggs). In the end, these high points of the series are not significant enough to truly distinguish A Place Further from the Universe from many other enjoyable shows.


As I conclude this review, I would like to note that this is certainly a subjective review. Hopefully, my unprofessional critiques don’t repel anyone from experiencing a potential wonder of his or her own world. I’m just here to say that, in my opinion, this series could have done much better, but was still a journey I had fun with. I conclude by admitting A Place Further than the Universe is currently a gem to the anime community. In my perspective, however, this series is simply in a place of convenience and comfort.

For me there is nothing better in life than to get on a plane to take a trip to a country that is not yours to know new places; This is much better when you travel with your friends or the people you love the most and even better if your traveling companions are willing to accompany you to the end of the world (literally, as in this anime).
* Story: Travel to Antarctica? It sounds like a crazy adventure but at the same time epic, right? But this time they knew how to handle it very well, the friendship of these four girls will faceups and downs during the trip in a harsh environment that is not very common to see, the story keeps the emotion for the final part and shows the post depression -Travel that is frequent to experience after the trip of your life is over.


* Characters: When you plan a trip, it's just beautiful when on the way you're joined by people who, although they have different histories, share the same feeling for knowing new places, something similar happens with this story and makes its characters help carry it forward the history.


* Sound: The OP and the ED are very good, the first expresses very well what the anime is about and the second transmits that feeling of wanting to see another episode more and more. The OST they use in the background (especially in the last two chapters is beautiful)


* Art: Fortunately Madhouse did not include those horrible colors in purple and red tones of NGNL, graphically this anime is well done, the characters well animated and the landscapes of Antarctica well done.


It was already a good time that I did not enjoy an adventure anime so entertaining and to some extent inspiring for those who like to travel, I prefer Kimari's reflection at the end of the anime and the last sentence that appears in the last 10 seconds of the last chapter ... who knows? Maybe one day I can also visit that Place Further than the Universe ....

A lot of people were prasing this show but I was skeptical at first thinking it was  just another overrated “moe girls” anime.
I was terribly mistaken. 
This anime was amazing,with astonishing visuals,beautiful soundtrack and a ton of emotions.The characters were fantastic and the story felt so wholesome.
The comedy was fresh and on point and the whole concept was new.The message was about friendship,bonds and overcoming obstacles in order to make the same bonds unbreakable in life. 
I’m really glad that I’ve watched it because leaving the unique experience  aside,this anime proved me once again that you should never judge a book by itscover.\n\n
You should definitly watch it because it wont disappoint.\n\n
Final rating:9/10.

A place further than the universe starts with a simple premise: a group of girls want to go to the Antartic for simple enjoyement of life and for searching the meaning or purpose of what is being alive and taking advantage of the time by doing productive things and making memories that can fondly be remebered as a good time in life and as a period of change.
The characters are likable and their design is almost perfect, they didn't presented a depht personality or too profound backstories but they still were capable of making us care for them. Shirase is a girl with a purposeand she does anything to reach that purpose, she knows what she wants to do and tries to make it possible, in her journey she meets Hinata an strange and curious girl who hates boring things and eventhough behaves childihsly has more real world experience than the other girls, Shiraishi who has been working since she was a child in her mother policy although she is in her first year of Higschool making her mind's age greater than her physical age and Tamaki who eventhough is the most careless of the four and behaves without fear nor regrets always care for her friends in every and any situation. Together they embark in a journey like no other they have ever done.


The music isn't great or memorable but is well-placed and enhances any moment in which is played making it enjoyable and likable, the opening is good but isn't the best that could have been used for the type of anime, the Ending is well-though and entones with the anime. The Ost is good and can even be listened as stand-alone without needing to watch the anime because although it isn't great tecnically, it can still be enjoyable like the best ones.


In conclusion this is a worth-watching and enjoyable anime with a likable cast of characters and an enjoyable music to accompany it. It isn't life changing or one that can be considered a classic but it's a cute light hearted anime that also covers depht themes if you dig profoundly into it.

There are a lot of shows similar to this. Where the basic story is that a group of girls hang out and all kinds of miscellaneous events happen. We have shows like K-on, lucky star, and Kinmoza. But for some reason, I haven't really enjoyed any of them that much (Except for Lucky-star). They didn't really have any underlying themes that I could resonate with.
But that's something "A place further than the universe" does really well. 
It manages to combine "moe" elements with interesting themes of friendship and goals. You can enjoy watching these cute anime girls while being interested in the underlying themes ofthe story. And I really liked that aspect of the show. 

I have seen shows like this that I like more, for example, yuru camp and Kobayashi's dragon maid, this is the first time I have liked a show so much because of that combination.


Of course it had flaws. It got a little boring after the first half and some of the character designs were a little too similar. But I could overlook it because it was so fascinating to watch the show. A show I wasn't too hyped to watch at first.



So yeah. The show was really good. 8/10

SORA YORI IS ONE OF THE FIRST ANIMES THAT I ACTUALLY EXPERIENCED TRUE SLICE OF LIFE. 


and now for sure, everytime Antarctica is brought up in real life, my memory will just remind me of "A Place Further Than The Universe".

A Place Further Than the Universe is a real gem, so far this has been the best anime i've seen this year, i'll avoid spoiler in this review because a lot of people have not seen it yet, please do.
At first i was going to skip it because it didn't seem very interesting, but after a lot of recommendations i decided to watch it and my god did it live up to the expectation.
On a technical aspect this anime is great, the animation and cinematography especially are beyond what one would expect from a slice of life show, you can cleary see they put greateffort into it.


All the characters are fun and enjoyable, a special mention go to Shirase who had a fantastic character development from start to finish and has a great personality, in short she's best girl.


Dialogues and comedy timing were all on point, great interaction beetween characters and realistic potrayal of real friendship and how it can help you reach your dreams.


The emotional moment, that can feel very cheesy in some anime, really hit home and they felt real (especially the ending of episode 12), this is a really inspiring anime which i vividly recommend.


IN CONCLUSION: this is a incredible anime that everyone should watch, it's very inspiring and touching with great characters and some great emotional moments.


My score for A Place Further Than the Universe is 9.5/10, one of the best anime i've seen in my life and so far the best of the year, please don't skip this one is really worth your time.

Having waited for the summer season to fully unfold before coming back to review Toibasho, this project can definitely hold its own as an original TV anime against its contemporaries (from 2017 season to S18, excluding continuing series or franchises). Sharing the label of Shoujo and nichijou genres which have been progressingly cliched since 2014, to produce a work that could rival greats such as K-ON is surely not easy. Quite a few examples in this genre after 2014 even suffer teathing quality issues that could really bug the picky consumers such as myself. But Toibasho have definitely surpassed the bar in term of basicquality, and the story is grabbing enough with the overflowing passion and intricate deliniation of interpersonal relationships so that character and plot does not feel flat at all.

Story (6/10):
For me, the story had a good concept. It was interesting that these girls all had different reasons for wanting to grow, for wanting to go to Antarctica, but... I don't know. The story wasn't exactly BAD per say, but it felt like it was taking too long to reach the point. I stopped on episode 4 and it still seemed like they were nowhere close to reaching Antarctica. I'm not saying it needs to be simple but... I don't know, I just felt like it wasn't interesting at all to me as I kept watching.
Art (9/10):
The art itself, I must admit, is quitepleasing to look at. It's a soft art style but it's really appealing to my eye. I think it was one of the things I better liked about the anime.


Sound (5/10):


I really don't have much to say about it other than "eh." None of the tracks were really interesting to me regardless. Not necessarily bad, but not music that I care enough about to listen to consistently.


Character (7/10):


The characters were entertaining enough and I enjoyed seeing them laugh and interact and I thought they were pretty cute. I like how they all had their own issues and aspirations and are unique in every way. I wasn't particularly attached to them in a way that I could rate this higher than a 7 though.


Enjoyment (6/10):


As I said before about the story, it wasn't necessarily bad, but it didn't grab me in the way that it grabbed others. To be honest, I started this on a whim because MANY people told me they loved it and recommended it and I thought that maybe I should stop being hard on it and give it a try. Unfortunately, it didn't work out the way I thought it would. It just isn't really my type of show at the end of the day.


Overall (6/10):


I seem to be the odd one out in this one with one of the lower ratings on the series. I don't necessarily think it's bad, but I don't think it's anything even remotely close to a masterpiece, nor did I think it was worth continuing. That said, I would still suggest this to someone else because it seems like more people liked it than disliked it like myself. I just have never particularly been one for this type of anime and I knew that going in, but thought I would at least try it like many others recommended to me.

Why should you watch Sora yori mo Tooi Basho?
Story is Very Good (8). What I love about A Place Further than the Universe is how it takes on the coming of age story genre, how real the setting and the situation feels for the 4 main characters, and how they experience voyage to Antarctica. Yes, there is nothing new on the circumstances that they encounter, but how they are executed are well done. Every time I watch an episode of this anime, I feel refreshed and excited on what would happen next, and that is what is good about Sora yori mo Tooi Basho. 
Artis Great (9). Madhouse being the studio responsible for the animation of this anime is one of the greatest thing about Sora Yori. The visuals are great where and when it is needed the most. The vibrant and shining colors, the fresh look of all the characters and that signature overall quality that madhouse produces is simply beautiful in my eyes.


Sound is Great (9). "The Girls Are Alright!" by saya is one of the best setup song to hype you up for the incoming adventures that the 4 main characters are gonna face head on. And partnering it up with the opening animation, Perfect! The ending song "Koko kara, Koko kara (ここから、ここから)" by the Main Characters' Seiyuu is the superb way to end each fun and adventure filled episode. And Kana Hanazawa the voice of Shirase was the one who got me to watch this anime so that is a plus for me!


Characters are Very Good (8). For the characters of the story I would just be focusing on the 4 Mari, Shirase, Hinata, and Yuzuki because they are essentially the heart of the story. I am 50/50 on the characters as Shirase and Hinata have the most personality of the bunch they are vibrant, quirky and adorable. However, Mari and Yuzuki lacks a lot of personality. At some point they felt like a plot tool to move the story forward which makes me feel disappointed so what should be a 9 was down to 8.


If I look at the anime in parts I have a mixed feeling about it, but as a whole  looking back at it; it was an enjoyable story to watch. It makes me want to go out and experience the world for its beauty. 


8 penguins out of 10.

A Place Further Than the Universe - An Anime That Deserves the Universe
I’ve rewatched it now several times so I can take in everything I may have missed the previous times.
Want to know how I know that this series is one of the most impactful I’ve ever watched? I’ve felt the same way I watched it the first time, each time I’ve rewatched it. The exact same emotions, sentiment and lessons learned.
Simply put, it’s one of the best executed anime I’ve ever seen. Every minuscule detail is crafted expertly. Every character is so well thought-out and lovable, blessed with deep stories and characteristics. The soundtrackis excellent and matches each scene perfectly. The animation is beautiful. The voice acting is top-tier. Its pacing is on point.


It does what many do to fail: take a seemingly simple premise and raise it to a whole new level. It’s quite simple, really. Four high school girls adventure down to Antarctica in search of something they all individually desire. Some desires are premeditated and crafted, others are impromptu. Regardless, each girl has their reasons for being there, and it’s one of the most inspirational aspects of the series. Despite heavy trials, personal afflictions, and the whole world dismissing their dreams, they never quit.


Few anime have sent me on an emotional rollercoaster quite like this series has: Clannad is another one to come to mind. Equally heartwarming and heartbreaking, it’s quite an experience to watch.


Where it really drew me in is its unapologetic authenticity. Beyond the lofty dreams and desires of the characters lies very compelling interpersonal relationships. They’re so authentic and real, it’s not hard to imagine them in real life. The dialogue, the movement, the emotions and feelings, everything is very real. 


Even the adventure itself—the mundane tasks onboard the ship and on Antarctica—is compelling. I, of course, have no idea what a real Antarctica mission is like, but the anime does such a good job creating this environment that I honestly couldn’t tell how far it was from reality. 


This is one to remember and revisit for a long, long time. It’s my favorite now, and it may be my favorite ever.

I would like to make this review short because my tear is still running off my face when writing this review after watching the finale. 
A Place further than the universe, is an animation very special for me. The ending really hooked me up as I lost my mom 6 years ago. That finale finally made me cry. This never happened before when I watched Anohana or Clannad before, somehow this series just got me. Dang ninjas peeling onions! 
The story plot and character development is so freaking good, every episode, there is around 50% of character development time and the rest are plotted forgoing to the destination Antarctica. Each episode also includes some kind of motto that taught you about the life, each character also has their chances to show up on each episode's stage and telling their story and background to the viewers. I actually have a feeling that I am a part of the group when watching the series. I am one friend of theirs and they are also my friend.

What can I say, this show is fantastic for what it sets out to do. The art is astoundingly natural, and yet the style has something to it that sets it apart from other realistic looking anime I've seen. Most of the art in this show wouldn't be out of place in a movie.
The real strength of this show are the characters: the protagonists work SO well with each other in their almost-but-not-quite-yet-frienship, the secondary characetrs are background noise most of the time but still recognizable at a mere glance, and the ALL leave the impression of a shonen protagonist, driven to do and bebetter by a single, unwavering dream.\n\n
There are "negatives", if you want to see them that way: there is virtually no conflict, it's obvious since the first opening plays that they will achieve their goal. The lack of doubt in the "if" department can and probably has driven away people, but when you simply want to watch four girls so best that's impossible to define one as "best girl" interact, watch in awe while they do just that.
